dublin_core.dcvalue: OBJECTIVES To examine the reliability of manual tracking performance and its association with impairment and disability in individuals symptomatic of an upper extremity cumulative trauma disorder CTD METHODS Volunteer and physician referred subjects 100 control 140 CTD tracked a target cursor moving quasi randomly using a hand held stylus interfaced with a digitizing tablet Impairment was physician rated and the Disability of the Arm Shoulder and Hand questionnaire measured disability Subsamples of 25 subjects per group were tested on three occasions RESULTS Reliability of tracking performance was excellent ICC or 0 88 and sensitivity was 81 Performance was superior in controls p Under 0 001 and deteriorated as a function of impairment level p Under 0 001 Tracking and impairment rating explained 65 of the disability score CONCLUSIONS Tracking performance may be an important outcome for monitoring change over time and the impact of a CTD on function in everyday activities
Made available in DSpace on 2020-02-06T15:53:31Z (GMT). No. of bitstreams: 0 Previous issue date: 2007-02-23
Are deficiencies in manual tracking associated with upper extremity cumulative trauma disorders?
